search_result.title: Bluff City bicentennial: 200 Memphis music moments
search_result.text:
May 16, 2019, 7:00 a.m. ET

Music has always been a huge part of the Memphis. You could argue that it is the very essence of the Memphis experience.

With the city celebrating its bicentennial, we decided to scan the history books and The Commercial Appeal archives to offer survey of some musical moments that are fondly remembered or meaningful in ways both large or small.

This is by no means a definitive list or a linear history of Memphis music, but rather a selection of important dates, events, songs, records, people and places that helped shape that story.

Here are our 200 Memphis music moments:

1. W.C. Handy, the father of “The Memphis Blues,” is born Nov. 16, 1873, in Florence, Alabama.

2. 1877: Estimated birth year of Frank Stokes, regarded as the father of the "Memphis blues" guitar style. He started playing on Beale Street at the turn of the 20th century and his recordings with partner Dan Sane, as the Beale Street Sheiks, were among the most influential of the 1920s and '30s. With Sane, and on his own, Stokes cut nearly 40 sides for the Paramount and Victor labels. Stokes' work had a major impact on the era's biggest musical star, "The Singing Brakeman" Jimmie Rodgers.

3. A pioneering figure in the world of gospel music, Lucie E. Campbell is born on April 30, 1885. A singer and composer, Campbell's songs would become staples of African American churches and were covered by country stars like Hank Snow, Johnny Cash and Ernest Tubb.

4. The original Orpheum was built as the Hopkins Grand Opera House in 1890 and was renamed the Orpheum after it became part of that vaudeville circuit in 1907. It burned to the ground in 1923, and today's Orpheum was built on its footprint five years later. It was purchased and operated by Malco as a movie house until 1977, and reopened in its current incarnation in 1984.

5. Born on March 6, 1893, guitarist and songwriter Furry Lewis was a famed blues storyteller. After recording a series of influential sides in the 1920s, Lewis fell into obscurity, working as a street sweeper in Memphis. He was “rediscovered” 40 years later, his career reinvigorated by the blues revival of the 1960s.

6. Jazz pianist, composer and bandleader Lil Hardin is born in Memphis on Feb. 3, 1898. Hardin would go on to exert a profound influence in shaping the music and career of her husband, Louis Armstrong. Her songs would be covered by everyone from Ray Charles to Ringo Starr.

7. Jazz saxophonist, swing-era bandleader and Memphis musical innovator Jimmie Lunceford is born in June 6, 1902.

8. Born on Beale Street on Oct. 19, 1907, Nat D. Williams would become a major Memphis music figure without playing or singing a note. Williams was an influential figure as host of the Palace Theater’s famed Beale Street Amateur Night, as director of Booker T. Washington High School’s talent show, and as the first African American disc jockey in Memphis and a nationally renowned writer and journalist.

9. One of the world's great pianists, John “Peter” Chatman — better known as Memphis Slim — is born in Memphis on Sept. 3, 1915.

10. Sam Phillips — founder of the Memphis Recording Service and Sun Studio — is born Jan. 5, 1923, in Florence, Alabama.

11. Led by Will Shade, the Memphis Jug Band forms in 1925. The group — in various iterations — will make some 60-plus recordings for Victor Records between 1927 and 1932. Their recordings would influence later generations of artists, including Bob Dylan, The Lovin' Spoonful and the Grateful Dead.

12. Riley B. King is born Sept. 16, 1925, in Berclair, Mississippi, between Itta Bena and Indianola. The man who would become B.B. King is the great-grandson of a slave, and his childhood is filled with heartbreak. His younger brother died as an infant, his parents then separated and his mother died when he was 9. He was raised by his grandmother, who died during his teens.

13. Influential radio disc jockey "Daddy-O" Dewey Phillips is born May 13, 1926, in Crump, Tennessee.

14. Willie Mitchell — trumpeter, bandleader, record producer and architect of Hi Records — is born March 1, 1928, in Ashland, Mississippi.

15. Koko Taylor was a Shelby County sharecropper's daughter whose regal bearing and powerful voice earned her the sobriquet "Queen of the Blues." Born Cora Walton on Sept. 28, 1928, just outside Memphis, Taylor said her dream to become a blues singer was nurtured in the cotton fields outside her family's sharecropper shack. During her more than 40-year career, Taylor was nominated seven times for Grammy awards and won in 1984.

16. Jim Stewart — founder of Satellite and Stax Records — is born July 29, 1929, in Middleton, Tennessee.

17. Sonny Burgess is born in Newport, Arkansas, on May 28, 1929. Among the many greats who came through the doors of Sun Records in the 1950s, Burgess was universally regarded for both his musical skills and showmanship on stage. Burgess and his band The Pacers achieved rockabilly immortality with their earliest efforts for Sun — notably their 1956 debut single "Red-Headed Woman" backed with "We Wanna Boogie," which remains one of the rawest and most electrifying releases in the label's history.

18. In 1930 “The Singing Brakeman,” Jimmie Rodgers, releases “Blue Yodel #9,” a bit of bluesy braggadocio announcing his arrival in Memphis, as he strides the corner of Beale and Main streets.

19. Born Robert Calvin Brooks on Jan. 27, 1930, in tiny Rosemark, Tennessee, the singer who would come to be known as Bobby "Blue" Bland moved to Memphis as a teenager with his mother. It was in the Bluff City that Bland began a career that would ultimately see him honored and enshrined in the halls of multiple musical institutions: the Blues Hall of Fame in 1981, the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1992, and the Memphis Music Hall of Fame in 2012.

20. April 5, 1931: The birthday of “Cowboy" Jack Clement in Memphis. Clement first made his mark as Sam Phillips' right-hand man at Sun Records. He would record Jerry Lee Lewis' biggest hits and pen several others for Johnny Cash, before becoming a major figure in country music.

21. Musician, radio deejay and station owner, cult TV star, wrestling promoter, nightclub impresario and record label head Eddie Bond is born in South Memphis on July 1, 1933. A rockabilly star in the '50s, Bond gave early career boosts to everyone from guitar great Reggie Young — who began as a member of Bond's backing group the Stompers — to Sam the Sham and the Pharaohs, who got their start as the house band at Bond's Diplomat Club. Bond earned his nickname as the "Tennessee Legend Maker" bringing the story of McNairy County Sheriff Buford Pusser to light and launching the career of wrestling royal Jerry "The King" Lawler.

22. In tiny Brookings, Arkansas, guitarist and producer Roland Janes is born on Aug. 20, 1933. Janes was at Jerry Lee Lewis’ side during the Killer’s greatest triumphs in the ’50s, he served as the linchpin for the Sun house band, and he played a crucial role in the growth of garage music in the ’60s with his own Sonic studio. For the last 30 years of his life, until his death in 2012, he was resident engineer and producer at Sam Phillips Recording Service.

23. His given name was John Henry Cannon, but the world knew him as Ace. One of Memphis' great instrumental hitmakers, a session man at Sun and a pillar of Hi Records, saxophonist Ace Cannon was born on May 5, 1934. Hailed as "The Godfather of the Sax," Cannon cut 38 singles and 27 albums for South Memphis' Hi label during the 1960s and 1970s. With hits like "Tuff" and "Blues (Stay Away From Me)," Cannon became one of the company's signature stars.

24. On Jan. 8, 1935, Elvis Presley — the future King of Rock and Roll — is born in a shotgun shack in Tupelo, Mississippi, arriving 35 minutes after his stillborn twin, Jesse.

25. George Coleman is born March 8, 1935. The alto sax great will launch his career working with Ray Charles and B.B. King, eventually becoming one of the leading saxophonists in jazz, working with Miles Davis, Herbie Hancock and others.

26. In 1936, a concert venue in Overton Park was opened. The Orchestra Shell, as it was then known, was funded through a partnership between the federal Works Progress Administration, the Memphis Park Commission and the city of Memphis. As the opening day program noted, "This Orchestra Shell, a pledge to the future of music in Memphis, will long repay the city for its construction in the pleasure its facilities will produce to the half million visitors who enjoy Overton Park each year.” The renamed and refurbished Levitt Shell at Overton Park continues to provide great music to Memphians in 2019.

27. Lincoln “Chips” Moman is born on June 12, 1937, in Georgia. A gifted rockabilly guitarist and band leader in the 1950s, Moman went on to become one of the architects of Stax Records and author of some of the most enduring songs in the history of rhythm-and-blues and country music — from “Dark End of the Street” to “Luckenbach Texas (Back to the Basics of Love).” In addition to midwifing Elvis’ creative rebirth in 1969, Moman shaped Memphis’ American Sound Studios and its house band, generating the most prolific run of chart hits in history.

28. On March 15, 1938, world-renowned jazz saxophonist Charles Lloyd is born in South Memphis. Considered one of the true living masters of jazz, Lloyd's remarkable career has seen him play with Memphian Gerald Wilson's big band, replace Eric Dolphy in Chico Hamilton's group, work with Cannonball Adderley and record and perform with everyone from B.B. King to the Beach Boys.

29. Born Alvertis Isbell on March 15, 1940, in Brinkley, Arkansas, Al Bell started his career as a disc jockey in high school, spinning records at sock hops. Over the next 60 years, Bell would become one of the most important black music figures, running then owning Stax Records and serving as an executive for Motown.

30. The Big O arrives: Iconic Stax Records star Otis Redding Jr. was born on Sept. 9, 1941, in Dawson, Georgia.

31. Memphis music producer Jim Dickinson was born Nov. 15, 1941. Dickinson will become a session player for the likes of Bob Dylan and The Rolling Stones, a producer for influential groups including Big Star and The Replacements, a sometime solo artist and the patriarch of a small musical dynasty through his sons, Cody and Luther Dickinson of the North Mississippi Allstars.

32. On Dec. 19, 1941, Maurice White is born in South Memphis. He would ultimately move to Los Angeles, founding Earth, Wind & Fire, who became superstars in the 1970s, selling more than 90 million albums and creating classic hits like "September," "Shining Star" and "Boogie Wonderland." White died in 2016.

33. Carla Thomas — the Queen of Stax Records and one of the pillars of the South Memphis soul label — is born Dec. 21, 1942.

34. Elvis Presley makes his first public appearance, competing in a singing contest at the Mississippi-Alabama Fair and Dairy Show in fall 1945.

35. In November 1948, the teenage Elvis Presley moves to Memphis with his parents Vernon and Gladys Presley, eventually settling in the Lauderdale Courts housing project.

36. In 1948, famed country duo The Louvin Brothers move to Memphis, where they perform regularly and appear on the radio. Among the Louvins' many ardent local fans are Gladys Presley and her young son, Elvis. Presley would later open shows for the Louvins in the mid-'50s.

37. In 1949, Dewey Phillips will become the host of a radio show on WHBQ called "Red, Hot and Blue." His willfully eclectic show — which mixed blues, country, R&B and dance records seamlessly — helped prepare Southern audiences for the coming wave of rock 'n' roll, a revolution that Phillips helped usher in.

38. Guitarist Reggie Young moves with his family to Memphis in 1950 at the age of 14. A relative prodigy, Young was gigging professionally at age 15. He would go on to back local rockabilly singer Eddie Bond — putting his signature lick on Bond's hit "Rockin' Daddy" — before being hired away by country star Johnny Horton. In the late '50s Young would land as the house guitarist at South Memphis' fledgling Royal Studios/Hi Records, making hits with Bill Black's Combo, before going on to become part of the hit-making machine at American Sound Studios, and later the most in-demand session guitarist in Nashville.

39. On March 27, 1952, Sam Phillips officially launches Sun Records in Memphis, where he will go on to discover and record Elvis Presley, Johnny Cash, Jerry Lee Lewis, Roy Orbison, Carl Perkins and other pivotal rock 'n' roll stars.

40. In 1952, B.B. King scores his first hit record, the chart-topping R&B number “3 O’Clock Blues.” Over the next decade, King would release a steady stream of hit singles, helping him rise from the chitlin’ circuit to the pinnacle of black entertainment.

41. In June 1953, Elvis Presley graduates from Humes High School.

42. That summer Presley stops by the Memphis Recording Service, to record a demo of "My Happiness" and "That’s When Your Heartaches Begin." Presley paid $4 for an acetate, intending the recording as a birthday present for his mother, Gladys.

43. On July 5, 1954, the trio of Bill Black, Scotty Moore and Elvis Presley played for Sam Phillips in the studio of Memphis Recording Service. They played Bing Crosby's "Harbor Lights" and Leon Payne's "I Love You Because." Later, Elvis started fooling around and singing the Arthur "Big Boy" Crudup song "That's All Right (Mama)." Phillips loved what he heard. They worked on the song over and over late into the night until Phillips had a hit.

44. The sensation Elvis Presley caused with his spark-of-the-new 1954 milestone "That's All Right" heralded to many the arrival of rock 'n' roll. Clocking in under 2 minutes, the song hit the evening airwaves of Dewey Phillips' WHBQ-AM radio show "Red, Hot & Blue," as the disc jockey spun the tune a reported seven times the week after its July 5 recording.

45. On July 19, 1954, Elvis Presley’s "That's All Right" was released as Sun single 209.

46. The flipside of the “That’s All Right” single is "Blue Moon of Kentucky.” Originally recorded as a waltz in 1947 by bluegrass pioneer Bill Monroe, the song was a familiar hit in the South. Seven years later, at the suggestion of bassist Bill Black, Elvis would cut it himself, tarting up the tune with a hiccupy blues-pop reading during his famed July 1954 session at Sun, thus earning his sobriquet as the "Hillbilly Cat."

47. In January 1955, Elvis Presley meets “Colonel” Tom Parker, a promoter and manager who has worked with country stars Hank Snow and Eddy Arnold. Parker will sign on to manage Presley later that summer and oversee his career for the next 22 years until Presley's death.

48. Frank Stokes, the father of Memphis blues guitar, dies of a stroke in Memphis on Sept. 12, 1955. He is buried at Hollywood Cemetery. Stokes is inducted into the Memphis Music Hall of Fame in 2017.

49. A 1953 number recorded by bluesman Junior Parker and the Blue Flames, and produced by Sam Phillips for Sun Records, "Mystery Train" is reinvented in the same room two years later by Elvis for his final Sun single.

50. Elvis signs with RCA Records in November 1955. Colonel Parker negotiates the sale of Presley’s Sun contract to RCA for $35,000. This includes a $5,000 bonus for Presley.

51. Recorded in late 1955, Carl Perkins’ second single for Sun Records, “Blue Suede Shoes," was written in his bathroom on a brown paper bag at 3 a.m. Just a few months after its release in 1956, "Blue Suede Shoes" became the first song to simultaneously top the three major Billboard charts: Country, Rhythm and Blues, and Pop.

52. Signed to Decca, Elvis Presley peers Johnny and Dorsey Burnette team with guitarist Paul Burlison as the Rock and Roll Trio. Their influential version of jazz man Tiny Bradshaw’s “The Train Kept a-Rollin' is cited as the first use of distorted guitar. Before dying in a 1964 boating accident, Johnny Burnette mellowed into the pop idol singer of “You're Sixteen” and “Dreamin'”.

53. In 1956, Ferriday, Louisiana, piano phenom Jerry Lee Lewis auditions for Sun Records, where he records his rendition of “Crazy Arms” and his original "End of The Road.”

54. In April 1956, Elvis Presley, now signed to RCA, has his first national No. 1 hit, "Heartbreak Hotel."

55. Also, that month Presley signs a movie contract with Hal Wallis and Paramount Pictures.

56. In 1956, budding singer-songwriter Jesse Winchester arrives in Memphis as a teen. The mellifluously voiced author of “The Brand New Tennessee Waltz,” “Mississippi, You’re on My Mind” and “Biloxi,” Winchester will become a favorite of critics and fellow musicians in the 1970s and be covered by a wide array of artists from Wilson Pickett to Reba McEntire. Bob Dylan once comments that, “You can’t talk about the best songwriters and not include him.”

57. Sept. 9, 1956: Elvis makes the first of three appearances on “The Ed Sullivan Show,” attracting the highest ratings ever for any variety show, securing a whopping 80% of TV watchers.

58. On Dec. 4, 1956, Elvis Presley, Jerry Lee Lewis, Carl Perkins and Johnny Cash convene at Sam Phillips' Memphis Recording Service for a somewhat impromptu jam session and intermittent epistemological debate that came to be regarded as a milestone moment in popular music lore. The so-called "Million Dollar Quartet" would eventually come to be celebrated on record, in books and on Broadway.

59. In 1957, Royal Studio, the home of Hi Records, opens in a former movie theater in South Memphis, with an Ampex 350 mono recorder installed by chief engineer Bill Cantrell, a co-founder of Hi.

60. Elvis buys Graceland for $102,500 in March 1957. He moves into the home later that summer.

61. In May 1957, Elvis begins work on his third motion picture, “Jailhouse Rock,” for MGM.

62. A banker by day and country fiddle player by night, Jim Stewart forms Satellite Records, cutting the label’s first side in October 1957 with “Blue Roses."

63. Sun star Johnny Cash records the classic “Big River” in 1958. Written in Memphis, it’s the story of a heartsick man chasing his lover along the twisting route of the Mississippi River from St. Paul to the Bluff City.

64. Elvis Presley is inducted into the U.S. Army at the Memphis Draft Board. The King of Rock and Roll is assigned the serial number 53310761.

65. In 1959, Arkansas-born Charlie Rich releases “Lonely Weekends” on Sun, considered one of the most important records in the evolution of '50s rockabilly into '60s country-pop. Nicknamed ''the Silver Fox,'' after his mane of prematurely white hair, Rich would go on to score hit after hit on the country charts the '70s, including “Behind Closed Doors" and “The Most Beautiful Girl.” Sun’s Sam Phillips often described Rich as the most talented musician he’d ever worked with.

66. In 1960, Stax Records — now based in South Memphis’ old Capitol Theatre — releases a duet between Rufus and Carla Thomas titled “Cause I Love You,” which becomes a hit and draws the attention of Atlantic Records’ Jerry Wexler. Atlantic signs a distribution deal with Stax soon after.

67. Neighborhood musicians begin hanging around Stax's 926 E. McLemore Ave. studio, among them organist Booker T. Jones, guitarist Steve Cropper and eventually bassist Donald "Duck" Dunn and drummer Al Jackson Jr., who will form Booker T. and the MG's.

68. Elvis is officially discharged from active duty in the U.S. Army on March 5, 1960. He returns home to Memphis three days later.

69. In February 1961, Sam Phillips opens a state-of-the-art facility just a few blocks away from the old Memphis Recording Service. The new Sam Phillips Recording Service is located at 639 Madison Ave., where it continues to operate today.

70. July 1961: The Mar-Keys' instrumental "Last Night" on Satellite becomes a national hit. It's discovered that there's also a California label called Satellite, so the Memphis-based Satellite becomes Stax (created from the names Stewart and Axton).

71. Released in fall 1961, William Bell's classic Stax ballad, “You Don’t Miss Your Water," reaches the Billboard Hot 100.

72. Booker T. & the MG's (which stands for Memphis Group) record and release "Green Onions," which puts Stax on the charts in 1962.

73. Also in 1962, Johnny Jenkins comes to the Stax studio to record a single for Atlantic. During the last half hour, the studio time is used by Jenkins' 21-year-old driver, Otis Redding, who records a ballad he's written called "These Arms of Mine." It's released in October on Stax's subsidiary, Volt.

74. Willie plays: In 1963, Willie Mitchell releases “Sunrise Serenade” on the Hi Records label, the first of more than a dozen instrumental soul albums the trumpeter and band leader will record.

75. Rufus Thomas is 46 when his signature hit "Walking the Dog" becomes a top-10 smash on the pop charts for Stax Records in 1963.

76. In September 1963, Otis Redding comes back to Stax to record "Pain In My Heart."

77. B.B. King releases a 1964 concert album recorded in Chicago, “Live at the Regal,” which remains one of the great blues LPs. King’s guitar work would resonate especially strongly in Britain, where a generation of budding blues guitarists — from Eric Clapton to Jeff Beck to Jimmy Page — would feel his impact in the 1960s.

78. Born and raised in Memphis, Cassietta George began singing at her father's church as an infant and would become a legend in the world of gospel. George's 1964 classic “Walk Around Heaven All Day” — which she composed and sang — remains a standard of the genre.

79. In 1964, with the help of local songwriter and manager Roosevelt Jamison, gospel singer O.V. Wright enters the R&B field in spectacular fashion. The Jamison-penned, Wright-sung classic "That's How Strong My Love Is" (later covered by Otis Redding and many others) marked the first hit for Quinton Claunch's local Goldwax label and launched Wright's secular career.

80. Texas-bred, turban-wearing, hearse-driving Sam "The Sham" Samudio brings his group The Pharaohs to Memphis in 1964. They would cut the organ-fueled romp "Wooly Bully" at Sam Phillips' studio, and the tune's signature Tex-Mex count-off ("Uno, dos, one, two, tres, quatro.") would help the song sell millions of copies in 1965, and become Billboard's record of the year. Over the decades it's been covered countless times by everyone from Alvin and the Chipmunks to Bruce Springsteen.

81. In 1964, guitarist Mabon "Teenie" Hodges becomes a member of Willie Mitchell’s band. In 1965, his brothers Charles and Leroy would also join, playing organ and bass. They would soon add drummer Howard Grimes, thus birthing the core of what would become known as Hi Rhythm, the band that helped sire hits for Al Green, Ann Peebles, Otis Clay and many others.

82. Memphis disc jockey and television personality George Klein launches WHBQ-TV's popular teen music program "Talent Party" in 1964. Known on pop radio as "The Geeker in your Speaker" ("Geeker" being pronounced "Jeeker," a nickname inspired his initials, "G.K."), Klein befriended Elvis when the two boys met at Humes High School and he was Presley's best man during the singer's 1967 marriage to Priscilla in Las Vegas.

83. Eddie Floyd signs on with Stax as a songwriter in 1965 and would score a major hit as a solo artist the following year with his signature “Knock on Wood,” a song originally intended for Otis Redding.

84. In 1965, local teen garage band The Gentrys cut a million-selling smash called "Keep on Dancing."

85. Also in 1965, Atlantic brings Wilson Pickett to Memphis to record at Stax, and his three sessions yield classics including "In the Midnight Hour," "634-5789" and "Ninety-Nine and A Half (Won't Do)."

86. Jerry Lee Lewis drops his 1966 burner “Memphis Beat”: “I’m goin’ to Memphis where the beat is tough,” hails the Killer, who found his sound, fame and fortune here. “It makes you tremble and it makes you weak/Gets in your blood, that Memphis beat.”

87. In 1966, John Fry launches Ardent’s first commercial studio, at 1457 National. Ardent would become a hub for like-minded musicians and aspiring producers, including Jim Dickinson and Terry Manning, who would enjoy long associations with the studio.

88. In 1966, Johnnie Taylor signs to Stax, where he was dubbed "The Philosopher of Soul." His hits included "I've Got to Love Somebody's Baby," written by Isaac Hayes and David Porter.

89. Memphis garage band The Guilloteens release the minor classic "I Don't Believe" in 1966, the peak of a short-lived but colorful career that saw them signed to Hanna-Barbera Records — the label imprint of the famed animation company. A popular club draw in both Memphis and Los Angeles, The Guilloteens' fans included a number of celebrity supporters like the Righteous Brothers, the Byrds and Elvis Presley.

90. Though Aretha Franklin's physical presence in Memphis may have been short-lived — she was born here but moved at age 2, ending up in Detroit — her musical connection to the Bluff City was long-lasting. In fact, the whole history of Memphis music might have been radically altered had Franklin signed with Stax Records as she was once poised to in 1966.

91. Carla Thomas is the "Queen" of Stax to Otis Redding's "King." Their album “King & Queen” is released in 1967.

92. On May 1, 1967, Elvis Presley marries Priscilla Ann Beaulieu in Las Vegas.

93. In 1967, a contingent from Stax Records — led by Otis Redding, Eddie Floyd, Carla Thomas, the MG's and the Mar-Keys — head to Europe for a triumphant package tour.

94. On June 17, 1967, Stax star Otis Redding makes his breakthrough performing at the Monterey International Pop Festival.

95. In September 1967, Memphis pop-soul combo The Box Tops score a hit with "The Letter," which is recorded at Chips Moman's American Sound Studio and produced by Dan Penn. "The Letter" remained at the top of Billboard's chart for four weeks in 1967 and sells over 4 million copies.

96. Between 1967 and 1972, American — led by producer Chips Moman and house band the Memphis Boys — would cut 122 chart records, an unmatched achievement. This included the Box Tops ("Cry Like a Baby"), Dusty Springfield ("Son of a Preacher Man"), Neil Diamond ("Sweet Caroline"), B.J. Thomas ("Hooked on a Feeling"), Bobby Womack ("Fly Me To The Moon") and, most famously, Elvis Presley ("Suspicious Minds").

97. On Nov. 4, 1967, dynamite soul duo Sam & Dave (Sam Moore and Dave Prater) hit No. 2 on the Stax label with "Soul Man," written by Isaac Hayes and David Porter.

98. On Dec. 2, 1967, a recording of "Back Up Train" by Forrest City, Arkansas, native Al Green enters the R&B singles charts.

99. Dec. 10, 1967: Otis Redding and most of the members of the original Bar-Kays die in a plane crash in Wisconsin.

100. March 16, 1968: "(Sittin' On) The Dock of the Bay," recorded for Stax three days before Otis Redding's death, reaches No. 1 for the first of four weeks.

101. In 1968 and 1969, The Rolling Stones record songs by Delta bluesmen Rev. Robert Wilkins (“Prodigal Son”) and Mississippi Fred McDowell (“You Got to Move”).

102. Pioneering disk jockey Dewey Phillips dies in 1968 at the age of 42 from heart failure.

103. Also in 1968, Johnnie Taylor gives Stax its first big hit following the label's split with Atlantic. Taylor's "Who's Making Love" is one of the year's big R&B smashes.

104. Recorded on April 4, 1968, in the immediate aftermath of Martin Luther King’s assassination, “Hotel Lorraine” by Otis Spann would capture the pain of King’s murder. Driven by a mournful piano, death march drums and Spann’s wounded, needle-pinning howl, it’s both an elegy and an exorcism that ultimately tries to make sense out of the chaos of the moment.

105. Dec. 3, 1968: “Elvis,” the TV program better known as “The ’68 Comeback” airs on NBC-TV and is one of the biggest television hits of the year.

106. Elvis returns to Memphis in January 1969, working at American Sounds Studios with producer Chips Moman and the Memphis Boys house band. The collaboration between Elvis, Moman and the Memphis Boys would result in Presley's return to the charts, as “Suspicious Minds” reached No. 1, and the resulting album, “From Elvis in Memphis,” would become a gold-selling global smash hit.

107. Trumpeter Wayne Jackson and saxophonist Andrew Love made their early reputation as part of the house band at Stax Records in the 1960s. In 1969 they incorporate as The Memphis Horns, working with institutions like Hi Records and American Studios, and eventually becoming the most in-demand horn section in the world.

108. Stax producer and songwriter Isaac Hayes steps into the spotlight with the 1969 LP “Hot Buttered Soul,” which sells over 3 million its first year.

109. In 1969 Sam Phillips sells Sun Records to Nashville music entrepreneur Shelby Singleton. As chairman and CEO of the Sun Entertainment Holding Corp., Singleton would be responsible for mining the Sun archives with a steady stream of reissues and archival releases from the label's vaults. He developed the Sun brand, licensing the company logo for T-shirts and other merchandise.

110. First-generation Sun rocker Billy Lee Riley becomes one of the first artists signed to Singleton's reactivated Sun Records label in 1969.

111. Considered one of the greatest records of the era, British singer Dusty Springfield's "Dusty In Memphis" is released in March 1969.

112. B.B. King’s influence on a generation of rock musicians and guitarists would lead to his late-’60s/early-’70s crossover to the white market. King would have his biggest chart triumph with 1969’s Top-20 hit and Grammy-winning single “The Thrill Is Gone.”

113. Al Green meets bandleader and Hi Records vice president Willie Mitchell while on tour in Texas in 1969, and Mitchell signs Green to Hi. The two collaborate on Green's debut album “Green Is Blues,” birthing the singer's signature sound.

114. Joe Cuoghi, a founding owner of Hi Records, dies in 1970; Willie Mitchell takes charge of the label.

115. In 1971: Isaac Hayes' "Theme from Shaft" becomes the second Stax single to top national charts.

116. Willie Mitchell hits his stride in '71, arranging and co-writing Al Green's smash "Let's Stay Together." He would help pen many of the singer's massive hits, including "Call Me (Come Back Home)" and "I'm Still In Love With You."

117. In November 1971, John Fry's Ardent Studios — now doing much of the overflow recording for Stax — moves into a newly built complex at 2000 Madison in Midtown.

118. Feb. 12, 1972: Al Green's "Let's Stay Together" dislodges Don McLean's "American Pie" from its month-long reign at No. 1 on the charts.

119. April 11, 1972: With Oscar in hand and his grandmother by his side, Isaac Hayes, 29, returns to Memphis after winning the Academy Award for "Theme from Shaft."

120. The Staple Singers "I'll Take You There" becomes the third Stax single to top the national charts in June 1972.

121. In August 1972, Al Green's "I'm Still in Love With You" hits No. 1 on R&B charts and No. 3 on pop charts.

122. On Aug. 20, 1972, Stax Records presents almost its entire roster in a benefit for Watts community held in L.A.'s Coliseum. "Wattstax," as the $1-a-ticket concert was called, features the Bar-Kays, as well as the Staple Singers, Carla Thomas, Rufus Thomas and Eddie Floyd. Isaac Hayes is grand marshal. A film of the event is released the following year.

123. Fall 1972: Jim Stewart sells his interest in Stax to Al Bell.

124. In 1972, Chips Moman and American Studios close shop in Memphis and head to Atlanta to start a new studio, taking most of the Memphis Boys with him. Moman and company will relocate to Nashville a year later where they find success in Music City.

125. Following the success of their 1973 breakthrough, “Tres Hombres,” Texas blues-rockers ZZ Top would become regular habitués of the Bluff City, recording their next half dozen albums locally, mostly at Midtown’s Ardent Studios.

126. Spring 1973: Al Green and Hi keep rolling. Green's “Call Me” is released, with hits "You Ought to Be With Me," "Call Me" and "Here I Am."

127. For a couple of weeks in 1973, two of Memphis’ greatest icons, Elvis Presley and Stax Records, were joined together. Presley had a rich history of working in his hometown, launching his recording career at Sun Records in the mid-'50s and then reviving it at American Studios in the late '60s. By the early '70s — following his triumphant return to the stage and the road — he was looking to start yet another chapter by cutting a pair of sessions at the Bluff City’s hottest house of music, Stax Records.

128. Soul diva Ann Peebles releases the 1973 hit “I Can’t Stand the Rain." A native of East St. Louis, Illinois, Peebles was discovered by bandleader Gene “Bowlegs” Miller and arrived in Memphis in 1968. She quickly fell in with Hi Records, working first as a songwriter (often in tandem with her future husband Don Bryant) and then later as a solo artist. Under the tutelage of producer Willie “Pops” Mitchell, and backed by the Hi Rhythm section, Peebles would become an R&B hitmaker during the decade. In addition to 1973’s career-defining “I Can’t Stand the Rain,” Peebles would create a succession of deep-soul classics, including “I’m Gonna Tear Your Playhouse Down,” “I Feel Like Breaking Up Somebody’s Home” and “Come to Mama.”

129. In 1974, Isaac Hayes becomes part owner of the Bluff City's first professional hoops franchise, the ill-fated ABA (American Basketball Association) team, the Memphis Tams.

130. That same year Hayes stars in “Truck Turner.” The so-called "blaxploitation" film casts Hayes as Mack "Truck" Turner, a bounty hunter caught in a "pimp civil war." (When Turner visits a posh brothel, one girl purrs: "Check out that big piece of chocolate cake!") When Hayes received the Memphis Film Forum's "Memphian in Film Excellence" award at the Memphis International Film Festival in March 2007, he asked that "Truck Turner" be screened after the ceremony.

131. Fledgling piano man Billy Joel makes his debut in 1974 playing a series of concerts at Lafayette’s Music Room. Joel would return to the Bluff City half a dozen times in the next few years — opening shows at Ellis Auditorium and headlining other smaller venues like The Ritz. By 1977, with the release of his smash “The Stranger,” Joel finally took top billing in a big room, the Cook Convention Center.

132. Memphis power-popper Tommy Hoehn kicks off his solo career with the 1975 single, "Blow Yourself Up." He would follow that up with a pair of late-'70s LPs, “Spacebreak” and “Losing You to Sleep,” for the Powerplay and London Records labels.

133. In 1975, Rod Stewart asks Willie Mitchell to engineer and arrange his album “Atlantic Crossing.”

134. Al Jackson Jr., the drummer for the Stax house band and anchor of Booker T. & the MG's, is gunned down in his Memphis home on Oct. 1, 1975. The case is never solved.

135. On Dec. 19, 1975, Stax Records is forced into involuntary bankruptcy as federal marshals descend on the studio and seize the company and its assets.

136. Memphis power-pop band Big Star records its dark masterpiece "Third/Sister Lovers" in 1975. It eventually is named one of Rolling Stone magazine's "500 Greatest Albums of All Time."

137. On Jan. 15, 1976, a bankruptcy judge orders the closing of Stax Records.

138. In 1976, the newly ordained Rev. Al Green records a final album, "Have a Good Time," with Willie Mitchell and Hi Rhythm. Green would leave his longtime creative home for his own newly built American Music studio, where he would self-produce the spiritually resonant masterpiece "The Belle Album." His Hi label swansong "Truth N' Time" came out in 1978. After that, he abandoned secular music entirely for a decade, finding comfort (and considerable success) as a gospel artist.

139. In 1977, Stax Records' assets and master recordings are sold to Berkeley, California-based Fantasy Records. Also that year, noted civil rights attorney Irvin Salky would help create one of Memphis’ defining events. An ardent champion of Mid-South music, as an artist manager, Salky helped revive the careers of jazz pianist Phineas Newborn and bluesman Furry Lewis. In 1977, he personally funded and launched the inaugural Beale Street Music Festival.

140. Elvis Presley dies on Aug. 16, 1977. He was 42.

141. In 1978, the Rolling Stones play the Mid-South Coliseum. The crowd roars as the house lights go down, but the moment brings a surprise as a stagehand sets up a metal folding chair for blues legend Furry Lewis to sit on while as he plays his second opening gig for the Stones in Memphis.

142. On Dec. 9, 1978, the final single released on the Stax label, the Bar-Kays' "Holy Ghost," enters the R&B charts.

143. In the early morning hours of Dec. 27, 1978, Big Star co-founder Chris Bell was driving home to East Memphis from Ardent Studios when he lost control of his car and crashed into a light pole at the intersection of Poplar and Grove Park. He was killed instantly. Bell, 27, would become iconic over the next four decades as the legend of Big Star grew.

144. Released in 1979, the compilation album "Beale Street Saturday Night" was commissioned — arguably at Beale Street's nadir — by the now-defunct Memphis Development Foundation as a fundraiser for their attempts to restore the historic Orpheum Theatre, which had fallen into disrepair. It featured blues legends Furry Lewis and Sleepy John Estes, folk artists Sid Selvidge, and Hi Records stalwart Teenie Hodges.

145. Drug-related health problems finally catch up with soul great O.V. Wright in 1979, after a severe heart condition weakened his body. He spent his final months in a hospital, checking out for a couple hours a day and heading to Willie Mitchell's Royal Studio to record what would become his final album. Eventually withered down to 115 pounds, Wright suffered a final heart attack while on the road and died on Nov. 16, 1980.

146. In 1981, Dr. George Nichopoulos, known as “Dr. Nick,” was acquitted on charges that he overprescribed drugs to Elvis Presley, Jerry Lee Lewis and seven others. Despite the acquittal, Elvis’ passing would haunt him over the next 39 years — and the once-respected physician would be hounded by medical board authorities and eventually stripped of his license in 1995. Dr. Nick died in 2016.

147. In 1982, Al Green wins his first Grammy, in the Best Traditional Soul Gospel Performance category, for "The Lord Will Make a Way."

148. In September 1985, Roy Orbison, Jerry Lee Lewis, Carl Perkins, Johnny Cash and producer Chips Moman convene for the recording of a project titled “Class Of 55." Moman recorded the reunion album using the four legendary rock 'n' rollers who got their starts in Memphis.

149. On Jan. 23, 1986, Sam Phillips, Elvis Presley and Jerry Lee Lewis are among the first class inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.

150. In 1987, singer-songwriter Steve Earle leaves the MCA Nashville label, switching to the company’s revived rock imprint, Uni, and comes to Ardent’s Memphis studios where he records the classic LP “Copperhead Road.”

151. Also in 1987, Minneapolis rockers The Replacements release a tribute song called “Alex Chilton.” Recorded at Midtown’s Ardent Studios, the anthem was a cockeyed homage to their friend, onetime producer and occasional road companion, the odd, inscrutable Chilton — singer for the Box Tops, leader of Big Star and iconoclastic solo artist.

152. In 1988, actor Dennis Quaid moves to Memphis for the filming of "Great Balls of Fire!," a Jerry Lee Lewis biopic released the following year that largely focuses on the Killer's relationship with his child bride and cousin, Myra (played by Winona Ryder).

153. Also in 1988, Rolling Stone Keith Richards asks Willie Mitchell to work on his first solo album; rock and pop stars, including Tina Turner, Boz Scaggs, John Mayer and many others would do the same over the years.

154. On Dec. 6, 1988, Roy Orbison died. The Texas-born tenor began his career at Memphis' Sun Records, where he achieved some small success with the rockabilly-flavored single "Ooby Dooby" and wrote hits for the Everly Brothers, Jerry Lee Lewis, Buddy Holly and Rick Nelson. In the early '60s, Orbison found his niche as a solo artist with a series of romantic, operatic hits including "Only the Lonely" and "Crying," and rave-ups like "Oh, Pretty Woman" and "Dream Baby (How Long Must I Dream)." Orbison enjoyed a late-career comeback as a solo artist and the centerpiece of the rock 'n' roll supergroup the Traveling Wilburys.

155. In August 1989, the original Stax studio is torn down.

156. September 1990 brings the first mention of future pop star Justin Timberlake in The Commercial Appeal as the paper reports on the results of the Mid-South Fair Junior Youth Talent Contest preliminaries. The paper notes that that vocal group category includes a combo called "More Than Wonderful, composed of Holly Gaines, 11, and Justin Timberlake, 9, both of the Memphis area."

157. As the CD boom hits in 1991, “The Complete Stax-Volt Singles, 1959-1968,” a nine-CD box set, is released.

158. Cult Stax artist Wendy Rene’s “After Laughter” is sampled by the hip-hop group the Wu-Tang Clan for the 1992 track “Tearz” off their “Enter the Wu-Tang (36 Chambers)” album. More than a decade later, the song was incorporated by Alicia Keys into “Where Do We Go From Here” on her platinum-selling 2007 album “As I Am.”

159. In 1992, Blues singer "Little" Laura Dukes, a mainstay of Beale Street and the Memphis music scene for almost 80 years, dies at 85. Born in Memphis in 1907, she was one of four children of Alex Dukes, a drummer in W.C. Handy's band.

160. The country of Ghana crowns Isaac Hayes a king for his humanitarian work in 1992.

161. Formed in the college town of Tempe, Arizona, in 1987, alt-pop band the Gin Blossoms would record a pair of hit LPs at Midtown's Ardent Studios. Their first effort, 1992's "New Miserable Experience" became a slow-growing hit, selling 4 million copies on the strength of radio and MTV favorites like "Hey Jealousy" and "Found Out About You." Their 1995 follow-up album, "Congratulations, I'm Sorry," earned them another platinum album and a Grammy nomination.

162. 1993: Rap duo 8Ball & MJG (Premro Smith and Marlon Jermaine Goodwin) release their first tracks. The pair emerge from Ridgeway Middle School and Orange Mound to become one of the city's most popular and respected rap acts, releasing eight albums in total. In 2018, the group becomes the second hip-hop act (following Three 6 Mafia) to be inducted into the Memphis Music Hall of Fame.

163. In 1993, Oblivians member Eric Friedl founds the Goner Records label in order to release “Wolf Rock,” an album by Japanese garage outfit Guitar Wolf. More than 25 years later, Goner’s empire — led by Friedl and longtime partner Zac Ives — includes a still-flourishing label (now with more than 100 releases to its credit), a thriving Cooper-Young-based retail store, mail-order business and the annual Gonerfest concert extravaganza, which draws bands and fans from all over the world to town each September.

164. In 1994, eight of Robert “Wolfman” Belfour’s songs are featured on musicologist Dr. David Evans’ compilation album “The Spirit Lives On, Deep South Country Blues and Spirituals in the 1990s.” After gaining the attention of Mississippi’s Fat Possum, Hill Country bluesman Belfour releases a pair of much-lauded albums — 2000’s “What’s Wrong with You” and 2003’s “Pushin’ My Luck” — for the label.

165. Esteemed Memphis folk singer Sid Selvidge becomes executive producer of the Beale Street Caravan radio show in 1996, leading the internationally syndicated show until his passing in 2013.

166. In 1997, Isaac Hayes lends his voice to the smooth-talking, sweet-love-making Chef on "South Park," a role he will perform for nearly a decade.

167. In 1998, Fox’s “That '70s Show” premieres, using a version of Memphis band Big Star’s “In the Street” as its theme song.

168. In 1999, Bob Dylan and Paul Simon brought their co-headlining tour to Downtown's Memphis' Pyramid. Dylan saluted his old running buddy, The Man in Black, with an inspired version of Johnny Cash's 1956 chart topper, “I Walk the Line."

169. In 2000, Three 6 Mafia featuring the Hypnotize Camp Posse put out the song “M.E.M.P.H.I.S.”

170. Spring 2001: Ground is broken on the Stax Museum of American Music in Memphis, at the site of the old studios.

171. On Dec. 16, 2001, Rufus Thomas, the man known as the “world’s oldest teenager” — and one of the Bluff City's most influential and colorful entertainers, with a career that spanned more than 70 years — dies at the age of 84.

172. Hailed as rock 'n' roll's great architect, Sam Phillips, 80, dies at Memphis St. Francis Hospital of respiratory failure on July 30, 2003.

173. The Stax Museum of American Soul Music is opened in May 2003. The museum campus in South Memphis will eventually include the Stax Music Academy and Soulsville Charter School.

174. Memphis rapper Yo Gotti releases his city-wide celebration “Reppin’ North Memphis" in 2003: “Yo Gotti from the north so you know what I’m about/But still kick it tough with my thugs in the south.”

175. The Johnny Cash biopic “Walk the Line" — starring Joaquin Phoenix and Reese Witherspoon — wraps shooting in Memphis on Sept. 1, 2004. The film will become a box office hit and Oscar winner when it is released the following year.

176. At the 78th annual Academy Awards in 2006, Memphis rappers Three 6 Mafia make history by winning Best Original Song for “It’s Hard Out Here for a Pimp,” their soundtrack contribution to the Craig Brewer film "Hustle & Flow." Three 6 become the first rap group to win an Academy Award and the first rap act to perform at the Oscars.

177. MTV's reality show, "Adventures in Hollyhood," about Oscar-winning rap group Three 6 Mafia, premieres on April 5, 2007.

178. In 2008, Willie Mitchell receives the Trustee's Award from the Grammy Foundation at ceremonies in Los Angeles, honoring his lifetime achievements.

179. B.B. King remained dedicated to his Delta roots. For more than 30 years, he performed an annual homecoming concert in Indianola, Mississippi. In 2008 came the opening of The B.B. King Museum and Delta Interpretive Center — a gleaming 20,000-square-foot, $14 million facility celebrating his life and career.

180. In summer 2009, Memphis lost one of its truly unique rock 'n' roll characters, Billy Lee Riley. Considered by many to be Sun Records' lost giant, Riley was a true multi-threat: He possessed the myriad musical gifts of Carl Perkins, the unhinged spirit of Jerry Lee Lewis, and the punkish insouciance of Elvis Presley — yet fate never rewarded Riley beyond cult acclaim.

181. In September 2009, Poplar Tunes, the iconic record store — where Elvis Presley shopped, which deejay Dewey Phillips championed, and whose success helped fund Hi Records — closed its doors abruptly. The original location at 308 Poplar — founded by Joe Cuoghi and John Novarese just after World War II — and a second site at 4622 Faronia called Pop Tunes were shut down by Music City Record Distributors, the Nashville-based company that acquired the stores in 2001.

182. The career of punk rock polymath Jimmy Lee Lindsey Jr., better known as Jay Reatard — the creative force behind the Reatards, Lost Sounds, Final Solutions and Angry Angles — is cut short when he dies in his Cooper-Young home on Jan. 13, 2010.

183. One of Memphis' most beloved and inimitable blues figures, Wilroy Sanders dies in February 2010. Sanders was founder and leader of Memphis blues outfit the Fieldstones and owner of the old Green's Lounge. Sanders was the subject of a 1999 video documentary, produced by local music label Shangri-La Projects, titled "The Last Living Bluesman."

184. In March 2010, Alex Chilton, the pop hitmaker, cult icon and Memphis rock iconoclast best known as a member of 1960s pop-soul act the Box Tops and the 1970s power-pop act Big Star, dies in New Orleans at the age of 59.

185. Legendary Mississippi bluesman Willie "Pinetop" Perkins becomes the oldest Grammy Award winner in history when "Joined at the Hip," his LP with fellow veteran Willie "Big Eyes" Smith, took home the trophy for Best Traditional Blues Album at the 2011 ceremonies. The Belzoni-born pianist would die just a month later at age 97.

186. In 2012, the Memphis Music Hall of Fame enshrines its inaugural class at the Cannon Center, inducting Bluff City icons like W.C. Handy, Elvis Presley, B.B. King, Jerry Lee Lewis and Al Green; and lesser-known figures like jazz saxophonist George Coleman, gospel songwriter Lucie Campbell, and Booker T. Washington high school bandmaster W.T. McDaniel.

187. Feel Like Going Home: 2013 saw a pair of musical sons return home. Alabama native and longtime Memphis hitmaker Dan Penn came back to play his first local show in 16 years. Penn’s two-set, 2 ½-hour concert at Rhodes College was a reminder of why he’s considered one of the pillars of Southern soul. Similarly, Sam & Dave’s Sam Moore returned after 16 years as well. Moore was the honored artist and performer at the annual Blues Ball, and his mild estrangement from his old label home ended with his emotionally charged first visit to the Stax Museum.

188. Bruno Mars comes to Memphis in 2014 as producer Mark Ronson enlists him and his writing partner Philip Lawrence to work on the track "Uptown Funk," which was partly written and recorded at South Memphis' Royal Studios. The track would become one of the biggest pop hits of the decade (and earn Royal engineer Boo Mitchell a Grammy honor).

189. Taking place on what would’ve been Elvis Presley’s 80th birthday in 2015, the singer’s first recording, a 78 mm acetate of the songs “My Happiness” and “That’s When Your Heartaches Begin” cut at the Memphis Recording Service in 1953, was auctioned off at Graceland. The disc sold for $240,000 and was won by an online bidder who “wishes to remain anonymous” — but turned out to be contemporary rock star Jack White.

190. A musical giant, cultural icon and pre-eminent influence on guitarists for more than 60 years, B.B. King was singularly synonymous with the blues music he loved and helped turn into a global touchstone. The Mississippi-born legend died at his home in Las Vegas on May 14, 2015.

191. In 2015, Memphis singer-songwriter Julien Baker releases her solo debut, "Sprained Ankle." The disc — which will make Baker one of the most acclaimed talents to emerge from Memphis in years — was recorded while she was still a student at Middle Tennessee State University.

192. Farewell to Ben Cauley. Though he may not have been as well-known as some of his Stax Records brethren, the trumpeter and longtime Bar-Kays member seemed to symbolize so much about the label and the city of Memphis itself. Cauley was the sole survivor of the 1967 plane crash that claimed eight people, including Stax star Otis Redding, and the rest of his fellow Bar-Kays bandmates. Yet, despite the crash and subsequent setbacks, Cauley’s life was not defined by tragedy, but rather overcoming it. Cauley died in 2015 at the age of 67 — but his joy for life and music were plentiful, and his triumph absolute.

193. Justin Timberlake becomes the youngest member of the Memphis Music Hall of Fame during ceremonies at the Cannon Center in October 2015. He accepts his award to a standing ovation. “I never prepared a speech for anything,” he said, by way of introduction. “But this is the (expletive) coolest thing that’s ever happened to me.”

194. One of the foundational figures in rock 'n' roll, a profoundly influential guitarist, and the musician who helped Elvis Presley become The King, Scotty Moore dies in Nashville on June 30, 2016, after a period of ill health. He was 84.

195. Yo Gotti got his start in the mid-'90s as one of the city's quintessential street rappers before transforming into a mainstream star. That unlikely chrysalis came about with partnership between his label CMG and Epic Records and the release of "I Am" in 2013. But it was "The Art of Hustle," released in 2016, that finally gave Gotti wings. The album debuted at No. 4 on the Billboard album charts, hit No. 1 on the R&B/hip-hop charts, and quickly proved a breakthrough for the veteran MC.

196. Memphian William Eggleston releases "Musik" in 2017. The disc is a rather auspicious debut, coming as it does from the 77-year-old Eggleston, a man widely hailed as the father of color photography and one of America's greatest living artists. Eggleston's music credentials include use of his photographs on album covers by Big Star, Primal Scream, Jimmy Eat World and Spoon, among others. "Musik" finds him creating behind a keyboard rather than a camera.

197. In March 2017, Graceland officials formally opened a new entertainment complex. Public ceremonies marked the start of a four-day grand opening celebration for "Elvis Presley's Memphis," a 200,000-square-foot, $45 million project across from Presley's mansion in Memphis' Whitehaven neighborhood.

198. In October 2017, the first Mempho Music Fest marks the return of major concerts to Shelby Farms Park. the event is highlighted by a mini-reunion of Booker T. & the MG's alums Booker T. Jones and Steve Cropper. Cropper notes, somewhat poignantly, that the deaths of the other MGs — drummer Al Jackson Jr., bassist Donald "Duck" Dunn and Lewie Steinberg — had left them as the last men standing. "It's just Booker T and the MG now," Cropper said.

199. Amazon Music launches its "Produced By" series, pairing notable producers with popular artists, both old and new. Inaugurating the project is multiple Grammy-winning Memphis engineer/producer Matt Ross-Spang. Spang produces four new tracks with Memphis soul legends Rev. Al Green and William Bell, singer-songwriting great John Prine and Americana darling Margo Price.

200. The Bar-Kays began as a local high school sock-hop band in 1964, became Stax soul hit makers in the ’60s, then were decimated in the 1967 plane crash that claimed most of the band and Otis Redding. The Bar-Kays' ’70s rebirth followed, as did a reinvention as snake-charming funk futurists. In 2019, their story — one marked by tragedy and transition and ultimately triumph — continues 55 years on. As ever, the Bar-Kays are a band in perpetual motion.

A Commercial Appeal subscription gives you unlimited access to stories that make a difference in your life and the lives of those around you. You also get the ability to tap into news from the USA TODAY Network's 109 local sites.

search_result.title: Trump, Musk shutter USAID and Food for Peace, a proud Kansas ...
search_result.text:
Feb. 4, 2025 Updated Feb. 13, 2025, 12:11 p.m. ET

President Trump and Elon Musk are shutting down the USAID, which houses the Food for Peace program.

Senator Roger Marshall acknowledges concerns about USAID but believes in pausing foreign aid spending.

Food for Peace, started by Kansans, has been a 70-year legacy of fighting world hunger using American agricultural surplus.

The closure of USAID and Food for Peace signifies a significant shift in American foreign policy since 1945.

Farmers in the Wheat State have a proud history of supporting international food aid, but President Donald Trump and billionaire Elon Musk could be ending a piece of that Kansas legacy that took seven decades to build.

The Food for Peace program is part of the U.S. Agency for International Development, or USAID, which Trump and Musk are in the process of shutting down. The federal government's webpage for the Food for Peace program appears to no longer exist, and neither does the rest of the USAID website.

Speaking with reporters in Topeka on Monday, U.S. Sen. Roger Marshall, R-Kansas, acknowledged the state's ties to Food for Peace while alleging that USAID was plagued by improper payments.

"It's something that I want to be part of, but I want it to be efficient, and I don't want the thugs stealing the food and stealing the money as well," Marshall said in response to a question from The Capital-Journal. "So I think there's a right way to do it; there's a wrong way to do it. I think it's very good to take a pause on all of our money that we're sending outside of this country.

"Let's make America first again. Let's get our own house in order."

But Musk's comments make his actions appear to be less like a pause in foreign aid and more like a permanent elimination.

Musk called USAID "beyond repair" and "hopeless" on Monday, USA TODAY reported. Then, in a post on X, Musk said, "We spent the weekend feeding USAID into the wood chipper." In a Sunday post, he said "USAID is a criminal organization. Time for it to die." In another, he said "USAID is evil."

Musk said he detailed his plan to Trump, and the president "agreed that we should shut it down" — even though the administration does not have congressional approval to close the foreign assistance agency.

Marshall, who is on the Senate agriculture committee, said he raised concerns about USAID with Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy, whom Trump tasked in November with establishing an informal Department of Government Efficiency.

"There is significant fraud and abuse, and we're just taken for granted," Marshall said. "As I travel to these countries, they just take us for granted. I've just never seen any more abuse than I have through the USAID program. As a matter of fact, this is one of the very first things I spoke to Elon and and Vivek about was the problems in the USAID program. There's just a whole lot of fraud, waste and abuse. We're not using it to our to our advantage anymore."

Food for Peace started in Kansas

Since the 1950s, Food for Peace has used America's agricultural surpluses to fight world hunger, expand international trade and advance foreign diplomacy.

The Robert J. Dole Institute of Politics at the University of Kansas has outlined the history of the Food for Peace program. So has U.S. Rep. Tracey Mann, R-Kansas, who celebrated its 70th anniversary last summer. The Kansas Association of Wheat Growers touted the history during a 2023 farm bill listening session.

"Over the past 70 years, Food for Peace has fed more than 4 billion people in 150 countries," Mann said in a July 2024 statement. "With the world facing a severe hunger crisis due to inflation, natural disasters, and global wars in Ukraine, Israel, and Yemen, Food for Peace is more important now than ever.

"I am grateful for the two brave Kansans who saw America's ability to answer the noble calling to feed a hungry world and to recognizing it as the morally right, strategically wise, and fiscally responsible thing to do."

The idea started in 1953 with Cheyenne County farmer Peter O'Brien, who shared it at a local Farm Bureau meeting. Fellow Kansan U.S. Sen. Andy Schoeppel sponsored the legislation, which was signed by President Dwight D. Eisenhower, another Kansan, in 1954.

At the time, according to the Dole Institute, "U.S. agricultural surpluses reached alarming levels, and storage of excess grain cost the government millions of dollars per year — even as the food deteriorated and became inedible."

The program "benefited the U.S. by decreasing food surpluses and by creating new markets for its agricultural products, while also providing many countries with starving populations some much-needed humanitarian aid."

Another Kansan, U.S. Sen. Bob Dole, authored an amendment in 1966 where American farmers, dubbed the "Bread and Butter Corps," would travel to developing countries to teach them skills for growing crops. He also pushed for language to exclude communist countries from benefiting. Food for Peace also led to other bipartisan food programs championed by Dole.

"This constructive use of U.S. farm abundance is one of the most inspiring activities ever undertaken by any country in world history," Dole said in an undated quote, according to the Dole Institute. "The program has helped the U.S. maintain its position as the world's leading exporter of food and fiber and shares U.S. abundance with friendly peoples abroad, effectively supplementing world agricultural trade."

At a 2023 farm bill listening session in Saline County, U.S. Rep. Glenn Thompson, R-Pennsylvania, said, "People with full bellies are less likely to engage in war and terrorism. And so that makes all of you and that makes the American farmer a champion for world peace."

Kansas congressional delegation has supported Food for Peace

The Kansas congressional delegation has supported Food for Peace in the past.

After Russia invaded Ukraine, U.S. Sen. Jerry Moran, R-Kansas, said, "Food stability is essential to political stability."

"It is critical to utilize every tool at our disposal to combat this worsening hunger crisis," Moran said in March 2022, noting that he is a member of the Senate Agriculture Appropriations Subcommittee that funds Food for Peace.

Moran also was a vocal supporter of foreign food aid when Trump proposed cuts during his first administration.

Mann, who is on the House agriculture committee, helped hold a sign touting USAID food aid in June 2023 while announcing the introduction of legislation to ensure Food for Peace uses American-grown commodities.

"America's international food aid programs have enjoyed bipartisan support for more than 65 years because they are simple, effective, and they feed millions of vulnerable people around the world each year," Mann said in a statement at the time. "Through these programs, America fortifies our allies, counters the influence of foreign adversaries, creates new markets and trading partners, and stops wars before they start."

Mann described the legislation as restoring the Food for Peace program's original intent. It also would have named the emergency assistance portion of the program after O'Brien. The bill — which was dubbed the American Farmers Feed the World Act — did not advance.

U.S. Rep. Sharice Davids, D-Kansas, who is also on the House agriculture committee, cosponsored a resolution last summer that would have recognized the successes of Food for Peace.

The resolution said in fiscal year 2022, Food for Peace helped 53 million people in 21 countries with emergency food assistance and nearly 3 million people with resilience-building development assistance.

Spokespeople for Moran and Mann didn't immediately respond to requests for comment on Monday. A Davids spokesperson declined to comment for this story, but pointed to a Davids op-ed in Newsweek where she called on Trump to focus on affordability issues while raising concerns about his government efficiency efforts.

Trump and Musk move to end Kansas legacy without congressional input

Are Musk and Trump killing a 70-year-old Kansas legacy?

"Yes, or at least it seems to be an attempt to," said Bob Beatty, a political science professor at Washburn University in Topeka. "It's hard to tell with this president. It's just hard to tell really what the intentions are."

Beatty said constitutional law scholars argue a president cannot shut down a federal agency, but at least some members of Congress are going along with it.

"It's a larger question of many members of Congress seemingly ceding their power to a president," he said. "That's interesting. The separation of powers was set up a long time ago for a reason, and one reason was because the president is not a king."

Beatty, who teaches an introduction to international relations course, said Republicans and Democrats after World War II supported aid for struggling countries with a belief it would prevent another world war.

"It was that post-war period of Truman and Eisenhower and Kennedy and every president after who believed that it was in America's best interests to alleviate chaos and disorder around the globe and for America to form friendships and alliances as well," he said. "That doesn't mean that a president is not allowed to completely change that idea, but if that is what is happening, it is one of the more significant changes in American foreign policy since 1945."

The principle, he said, was that chaos abroad is a threat to American security at home.

"Kansas has a special link to that foreign policy because Kansas farmers have been helping to supply food to countries that need it, and Kansas leaders have been strong proponents of it through all these years," Beatty said. "So if Donald Trump wants to change this policy, that's very possible, but it's also a striking change if Kansas senators and Congress people want to change it as well."

"It would be surprising if the Kansas delegation supports the wholesale dismantling of foreign aid programs, including Food for Peace," he added, "but I'm no longer surprised in the Trump era by many things."

Beatty said foreign aid is less than 1% of the federal budget.

"In pure dollar terms, it always looks like a lot of money, and it is," he said. "But as a percentage of America's budget, since 1945, American leaders consider it a bargain if it's going to significantly impact world peace and American foreign policy positively, which they decided it always has."

Jason Alatidd is a Statehouse reporter for The Topeka Capital-Journal. He can be reached by email at jalatidd@gannett.com. Follow him on X @Jason_Alatidd.

search_result.title: Institute of Peace sues Trump, DOGE - USA Today
search_result.text:
March 19, 2025, 3:22 p.m. ET

WASHINGTON − The U.S. Institute of Peace is suing President Donald Trump, the Department of Government Efficiency and others, following a series of conflicts between the nonprofit and the new administration that culminated in a tense building takeover earlier this week.

The lawsuit filed on Tuesday asks the court to reverse moves by DOGE to occupy the institute headquarters and install new leadership at the organization. On Monday, DOGE team members gained access to the building, with the help of local police from Washington, D.C.

Trump had targeted the Institute of Peace as part of his and billionaire ally Elon Musk's sweeping efforts to slash federal bureaucracy and workforce.

But the issue, representatives for the institute argue, is employees at the Institute of Peace are not federal workers. The organization, which was founded by and receives annual funding from Congress, is independent of the executive branch.

Tuesday's lawsuit alleges that, under this status, the DOGE team's dramatic building entrance and a string of other actions that have upturned institute operations are unlawful.

White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt criticized the peace organization's resistance, calling USIP employees "rogue bureaucrats."

"This is what DOGE and this administration is facing. It's a resistance from bureaucrats who don't want to see change in this city," Leavitt said in a briefing Wednesday. "President Trump was elected on an overwhelming mandate to seek change and implement change, and this is unacceptable."

A White House spokesperson did not address requests for comment on some of the lawsuit's more specific allegations but said in a statement to USA TODAY, "Rogue bureaucrats will not be allowed to hold agencies hostage. The Trump administration will enforce the President’s executive authority and ensure his agencies remain accountable to the American people."

What is the Institute of Peace?

The U.S. Institute of Peace was created by Congress in 1984, under then-President Ronald Reagan, and specializes in resolving violent conflicts globally, according to its website.

In a letter to the Office of Management and Budget earlier this month, George Moose, then widely recognized as the president of USIP, said the institute's work “fully aligns” with Trump's priorities when it comes to preventing conflict and keeping the U.S. out of wars.

“As has been the case throughout its 40 years of existence," Moose wrote, "the Institute is committed to the efficient and responsible deployment of taxpayer funds in cooperation with Congress and the Administration.”

The recent lawsuit also argues that USIP advances Trump's professed mission of increasing efficiency and effectiveness of government.

Yet, the lawsuit documents state, “the President declared the Institute 'unnecessary' and directed steps to curtail its vital work.”

DOGE probes began with Trump order

Issues between DOGE and the Institute of Peace began last month, when Trump signed an executive order directing four agencies, including USIP, to reduce their personnel "to the minimum presence and function required by law" within 14 days.

The order incorrectly labeled the institute as a “governmental entit[y]” and part of the “federal bureaucracy," the lawsuit claims.

The next day, DOGE reached out to the institute and set a virtual meeting for Monday, Feb. 24, according to the lawsuit. Three DOGE staffers were present, along with Moose and USIP counsel.

In the meeting, Moose and George Foote, USIP's outside counsel, outlined the institute's independent nature. According to Moose's recollection, a DOGE staffer said at the time "that they understood our position and would 'regroup.'"

Rumors of DOGE takeover start

Days after Moose sent his letter to OMB, the lawsuit says he started hearing about inquiries made by DOGE staffers regarding the institute's building security.

By then, members of Musk's DOGE team were known to have already gained access to the offices of multiple executive agencies, including the Internal Revenue Service's in Washington and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's in Atlanta.

Foote emailed DOGE staffers to let them know any “unauthorized personnel would only be admitted with a valid warrant issued by a court,” the lawsuit states. According to Foote, his message went unanswered.

President, board members ousted

On Friday, multiple board members received termination notices via email.

Lawyers for the Institute of Peace and several of these targeted board members argue their removals did not follow proper procedure and are therefore null. Members of USIP's board can be terminated for wrongdoing, such as a felony conviction; by agreement of at least eight other board members; or by a majority of members of multiple specific House and Senate committees, the lawsuit states.

Shortly after members received the emails, DOGE staffers arrived at USIP's office building near the Lincoln Memorial in D.C. They were denied entry, the lawsuit states, but returned again Friday evening, this time with FBI agents and a notice that the board now consisted of three people: Secretary of State Marco Rubio, Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth and National Defense University President Peter Garvin.

And, acting as the remaining fraction of the board, they had decided to remove Moose and replace him with State Department official Kenneth Jackson.

Rubio, Hegseth and Garvin are also named as defendants on USIP's lawsuit.

DOGE returns, find a way in

Sunday evening, Foote, Moose and USIP’s chief of security decided to terminate their contract with a private security company, Inter-Con, out of fear that DOGE would coerce the contractors into granting them access to the headquarters, according to the lawsuit.

The following afternoon, four members of Inter-Con's team arrived outside USIP's office. After they were first unable to enter with their now-deactivated security badges, one ex-employee brandished a physical key that USIP had not been able to confiscate yet, allowing the group to enter, the lawsuit states.

The lawsuit said that the building was put under lockdown, and Foote called Washington, D.C.'s Metropolitan Police Department. The contractors eventually left, after being warned multiple times they were trespassing

Jackson, the Trump administration's pick to be new USIP president, arrived later in a Black SUV. He spoke briefly with Foote and another lawyer, before leaving the premises.

Hours later on Monday, he and members of DOGE returned, this time to be let in by police officers who had just arrived.

In a statement Tuesday, the Metropolitan Police Department said that they were contacted and called to the scene by the U.S. Attorney's Office. Upon arrival, Jackson provided officers "with documentation that he was the acting USIP President."

According to the police department, all "unauthorized individuals" eventually vacated the premises without incident and no arrests were made.

As they were being led out, Foote said in the lawsuit he and others were told they would be able to retrieve their possessions at a later date.

As of the time the lawsuit was filed Tuesday, he said those belongings, including their cars, remain at the institute’s headquarters.
